quoteFirst: The weather was squally and the air full of mist when she reached the outer Banks, 900 miles from New York, shortly after sunrise on Sunday, March 16.  The big vessel was heading west by north, when,
quoteLast: , Second Mate Erichsen, who was on the bridge, saw emerge through the mist on the starboard side of the ship, at the distance of about a thousand feet, a towering column which united sea and sky.  The column was in front of the ship to starboard, and was moving in a southeasterly direction, apparently at the rate of eight knots an hour.
title:
The Jungle Fugitives: A Tale of Life and Adventure in India
Including also Many Stories of American Adventure, Enterprise and Daring
author: Ellis, Edward Sylvester, 1840-1916

quoteFirst: His landlord found him
quoteLast: in the morning asleep in an arm-chair.
title: The Rough Road
author: Locke, William John, 1863-1930

quoteFirst: At the same time the 2/4th Hants pushed into the village and fought their way right through it.  They had to sustain a heavy counter-attack delivered about {119}
quoteLast: by the Twentieth Hanoverian Division, supported by a flight of low-flying aeroplanes.  This attack was broken up with great loss by the steady fire of the men of Hampshire and Yorkshire.
title: The British Campaign in France and Flanders—July to November, 1918
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan, 1859-1930

quoteFirst: Cape Maria then bore N. 2° 30ʹ W. distant thirty-three leagues; our latitude by observation was 36° 2ʹ S. About
quoteLast: , we were within six leagues of it; but having a fresh gale upon it, with a rolling sea, we hauled our wind to the S. E., and kept on that course close upon the wind all night, sounding several times, but having no ground with one hundred, and one hundred and ten fathom.
title: The Three Voyages of Captain Cook Round the World. Vol. I. Being the First of the First Voyage.
author: Cook, James, 1728-1779; Banks, Joseph, 1743-1820 [Contributor]; Hawkesworth, John, 1715?-1773 [Editor]

quoteFirst: Before
quoteLast: in the morning, with a warm sunshine falling over everything, Nat was at work with Tempe’s mule hitched to the harrow; trying to get the ground ready for lettuce planting before the first frost fall.
title: Gritny people
author: Kennedy, R. Emmet (Robert Emmet), 1877-1941; Tinker, Edward Larocque, 1881-1968 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: along the shore, at the distance of about four leagues, with gentle breezes from between N. W. and N. N. E. At
quoteLast: , we saw the top of the peak to the southward, above the clouds, which concealed it below. And at this time, the southernmost land in sight bore S. by W.
title: The Three Voyages of Captain Cook Round the World. Vol. I. Being the First of the First Voyage.

quoteFirst: "When I arrived at Monmouth I found that Elder James Morgan awaited my coming, and had given out an appointment for me to preach in the town
quoteLast: , at the house of Robert Davis. There was a crowded meeting, and many were unable to get into the house. Four offered themselves for baptism.
title:
Wilford Woodruff, Fourth President of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints
History of His Life and Labors, as Recorded in His Daily Journals
author: Woodruff, Wilford, 1807-1898; Cowley, Matthias F. [Editor]

quoteFirst: I went home
quoteLast: to get the papers which had been promised me, but found a note telling me I would not get them until the next day.
title: The Physiology of Taste; Or, Transcendental Gastronomy
author: Brillat-Savarin, 1755-1826; Robinson, Fayette, -1859 [Translator]

quoteFirst: ‘Do you think they’ll reprieve me in the night, brother? I’ve known reprieves come in the night, afore now. I’ve known ‘em come as late as five, six, and
quoteLast: in the morning. Don’t you think there’s a good chance yet,--don’t you? Say you do. Say you do, young man,’ whined the miserable creature, with an imploring gesture towards Barnaby, ‘or I shall go mad!’
title: Barnaby Rudge: A Tale of the Riots of 'Eighty
author: Dickens, Charles, 1812-1870

quoteFirst: Bell after bell, from the great city beneath, tolled out
quoteLast: ; and Fra Luke knocked modestly at the gate of the college. His visit appeared to have been expected, for he was admitted at once and conducted to the large hall, which formed the waiting-room of the college.
title: Gerald Fitzgerald, the Chevalier: A Novel
author: Lever, Charles James, 1806-1872; McCormick, A. D. (Arthur David), 1860-1943 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: "Ling Wen will be sufficient.
quoteLast: to-night, monsieur, you will send an imperative message that you must see Ling Wen at once, and--No, that is all you need do. You will not skate? Then, _mon ami, au revoir_."
title: A Diplomatic Woman
author: Mee, Huan

quoteFirst: Perrenx of "L'Aurore," the jurors withdrew to consider their verdict which, by a majority of _seven to five_,[21] was one of guilty. It was
quoteLast: , the court-room, the whole Palais de Justice indeed, its precincts and the adjoining streets, were crowded with people among whom the professional anti-Semites and many officers were conspicuous. Yells of triumph greeted the news of the verdict, and were renewed when it was known that in Zola's case the maximum penalty of a year's imprisonment with a fine of three thousand francs had been applied.
title: Émile Zola, Novelist and Reformer: An Account of His Life & Work
author: Vizetelly, Ernest Alfred, 1853-1922

quoteFirst: As soon as we got out of the Sound, I stood over to the eastward, in order to get the streight well open before the tide of ebb came on. At
quoteLast: , the two small islands which lie off Cape Koamaroo, the south-east head of Queen Charlotte’s Sound, bore east, distant about four miles: at this time it was nearly calm, and the tide of ebb setting out, we were, in a very short time, carried by the rapidity of the stream close upon one of the islands, which was a rock rising almost perpendicularly out of the sea: we perceived our danger increase every moment, and had but one expedient to prevent our being dashed to pieces, the success of which a few minutes would determine.
title: The Three Voyages of Captain Cook Round the World. Vol. I. Being the First of the First Voyage.
author: Cook, James, 1728-1779; Banks, Joseph, 1743-1820 [Contributor]; Hawkesworth, John, 1715?-1773 [Editor]

quoteLast: in the morning.

quoteFirst: Ellen knew this was only reasonable, and tried to be as patient as she could under these trying circumstances; but when
quoteLast: came, and still no appearance of her dress, her case was truly piteous. Johnny volunteered to drive to town and bring it back with him, if his sister would get everything else ready; and with a heavy heart Ellen went upstairs to dress.
title: The Weird of the Wentworths: A Tale of George IV's Time, Vol. 1

quoteFirst: "First Betty--now you! I must indeed be an unwelcome guest in my father's house. Of course, I can't possibly stay now. There's a train from Leyburn
quoteLast: . I can catch it by leaving here at three, but I shan't start unless I go alone."
title: The House 'Round the Corner
author: Tracy, Louis, 1863-1928

quoteFirst: On March 5th, 1869, I again set out for Persia, _viâ_ Marseilles, leaving London at a quarter to eight A.M. I got to Paris at six P.M., took a cab for the Lyons station, caught the mail which left at a quarter past
quoteLast: , and arrived in Marseilles on the 6th at noon. Being very tired, I went on board at once, and succeeded in getting a state-room all to myself; slept till four. At five P.M. we started in a tremendous sea, dead-lights up, and the violin (planks fixed with cords to prevent the table equipage leaving the table) at dinner.
title: In the land of the lion and sun, or, modern Persia
author: Wills, C. J. (Charles James), 1842-1912

quoteFirst: They commenced at the first detachment
quoteLast: this morning and by night got as many as six, and gave orders up as high as eighteen to be ready to leave at a short notice. They ordered at first eighteen detachments to be ready, but could not find transportation for all to-day. They say they are ordered to Charleston to be exchanged.
title:
Life in Southern Prisons
From the Diary of Corporal Charles Smedley, of Company G, 90th Regiment Penn'a Volunteers, Commencing a Few Days Before the "Battle of the Wilderness", In Which He Was Taken Prisoner ... Also, a Short Description of the March to and Battle of Gettysburg, Together with a Biographical Sketch of the Author
author: Smedley, Charles, 1836-1864; Dobbins, Richard [Contributor]; Stubbs, Charles H. [Contributor]
